entry.title: UK government oil and gas sector strategy: call for industry's views
entry.content:
As part of its industrial strategy, the Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) announced that there will be, initially, 10 sector strategies, of which oil and gas would be one.

The industry’s input is essential as BIS and the Department of Energy and Climate Change (DECC) develop this work in partnership with Oil & Gas UK.

Sector strategies will be co-developed and implemented with industry to be durable and will:

  • be long-term in focus: developing a vision for the sector and what needs to happen from both government and business to get there
  • be co-created with industry: committing both business and government to specific actions to maintain and develop long-term capabilities
  • take a whole of government approach: looking across all of government to identify barriers and levers which have the biggest impacts and align these to deliver growth
  • engage across the totality of the sector: working with industry and identifying actions which benefit business across the whole supply chain whether they are large, medium or small

Publication is expected in late March 2013.

Industry’s views are very much welcomed particularly through January 2013 and can be fed into either:

BIS – Tom Worsley – Tom.Worsley@bis.gsi.gov.uk – 020 7215 6480

DECC – Audrey Banner – Audrey.banner@decc.gsi.gov.uk – 01224 254104

entry.title: Future Reserves 2020 Consultation
entry.content:
The United Kingdom’s Reserve Forces are a vital component of our Armed Forces; contributing to the public good we call Defence. They have made, and continue to make, a significant contribution to the Nation’s defence and security. But the security challenges the UK will face in future are different from those of the past, and for which our Reserve Forces are currently structured. Over the next decade, as Defence transforms to meet future and uncertain challenges, so the importance of our Reserve Forces will increase, and the way we organise and use them will change.

The consultation exercise will consider what changes are required to the Reserve Forces in order to generate and sustain the numbers and capabilities we need from them to meet our defence requirements. Specifically, we will look to define the right offer to attract and retain the individuals we need to serve in the reserves; the right relationship with the civilian employers of reservists; and the right support for reservists and their families across our communities.

The Consultation (Green) Paper sets out our thinking and direction of travel on Future Reserve. The key areas on which the paper focuses include:

  • How we will use Reserve Forces in the future
  • The offer for employers
  • The offer for reservists

Responses to the Green Paper can be provided online from early November. We encourage you to engage and provide feedback.

A White Paper in 2013 will detail the policy changes for Reserves and show how changes will be implemented to establish a new force structure such that we create the strategic conditions for success. Responses received during the consultation exercise will be used to inform the White Paper.

Any enquiries or questions about the consultation process should be directed to DCDSPers-RFC-FR20Consultation@mod.uk. Please note this email address should not be used to send responses to the Green Paper - these should be provided via the Respond Online link below.

entry.title: Live tables on local government finance
entry.content:
Capital forecast and capital payments and receipts

These live tables contain data derived from quarterly returns and the first annual forecast figures from local authorities. The tables present the latest available summary or detailed data relating to these inquiries.

The tables contain essential data supplied to the Office for National Statistics and HM Treasury. The data are used in compiling the National Accounts and the Public Sector Finances. The tables are updated as soon as new or revised data become available (hence the word ‘live’ is used).

Tables and detailed notes and definitions are grouped and can be found by area. The contents of our flagship publication Local Government Financial Statistics provide annual estimates consistent with the quarterly estimates published here.

Please note that the live tables do not include all of the data items we collect. All other topic based information such as statistical releases and reports can be found from the Local Government Finance statistics homepage. This also includes links to other Communities and Local Government and external sources of statistical information.

Highway maintenance expenditure on a non FRS 17 basis

This table contains data derived from local authority returns providing information on net current expenditure on highway maintenance for 2006 to 2007, 2007 to 2008 and 2008 to 2009 on a non FRS 17 basis. Notes and definitions are also provided.

Receipts of Council Taxes

This live table provides the latest data available on receipts of council taxes collected during a financial year in England. The information in this table is derived from Quarterly Return of Council Taxes and National Non-Domestic Rates Returns (QRC1-4) submitted to the Department for Communities and Local Government by English local authorities. The quarterly information is used in the local authority components of the National Accounts compiled by the Office for National Statistics. The table is updated as soon as new or revised data becomes available. Local authority level data will be made available once a financial year is complete.

Firefighter pensions

The firefighter pensions live tables provide the latest data available on Firefighter Pension Schemes income, expenditure and membership in England. The information in this table is derived from Fire Fighter Pension (FFP) forms submitted to the Department for Communities and Local Government by fire authorities. The table is updated as soon as new or revised data becomes available.

Borrowing and investment live tables

The borrowing and investment live tables provide the latest data available on local authorities’ outstanding borrowing and investments for the UK. The information in this table is derived from the monthly and quarterly borrowing forms submitted to the Department for Communities and Local Government by all local authorities. The table is updated as soon as new or revised data becomes available.

entry.title: Implementation of Port Security Regulations 2009 at certain ports
entry.content:
The purpose of Directive 2005/65/EC is to enhance security co-ordination in the wider area at certain ports. The directive requires the following:

  • designation of a port security authority
  • appointment of a port security officer
  • a port security risk assessment to be conducted
  • creation of a port security plan

The draft designation orders which we are are consulting on here append plan(s) outlining the area which the port security authority will have responsibility over.

entry.title: Foreign Office Spend over £25,000 for September 2012
entry.content:
The Coalition Government is committed to publishing departmental spend over £25,000 as part of its commitment to transparency and open government.

This is the Foreign Office spend in the UK for transactions totalling over £25,000 published by month. We have published our spend in line with Cabinet Office guidelines which allow for data protection of individuals and security constraints.

entry.title: Sennybridge firing notice
entry.content: Sennybridge’s firing times are presented in 3 file formats so that the information is accessible to everyone. The TXT format is browseable on mobile devices such as Blackberry’s, smart phones and tablets. The CSV format enables the MOD to post information on data.gov.uk, and therefore remain transparent.

entry.title: Department for Transport digital strategy
entry.content: This strategy describes the steps Department for Transport will take to deliver ‘digital by default’ services for all its customers. This means raising the bar for our existing digital services, bringing more services online, tackling barriers to entry, helping those not able to use digital to ensure no one is left behind and working digitally across the board.

entry.title: BIS monthly spend October 2012
entry.content:
The government is committed to setting new standards for transparency so the public can more easily see how and where taxpayers’ money is being spent and hold politicians, government departments and public bodies to account.

All central government departments must publish details of their spending over £25,000, and publish monthly information by the last day of each month.

entry.title: Dartmoor Training Area: the continuing need for military training on Dartmoor, 2005
entry.content: Report on the continuing need for military training on Dartmoor Training Area, 2005.

entry.title: Law Officers' Departments - Digital Strategy
entry.content: This strategy sets out how the Law Officers’ Departments will become digital by default. It fulfils the commitment made in the Civil Service Reform Plan.
